Award.AwardTitle: US-South Korea Collaborative Research: Additive Manufacturing of Fatigue Resistant Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Additive manufacturing, or 3D printing, offers the ability to fabricate customized, complex metallic parts traditionally unobtainable for a variety of applications. A paradigm shift in engineering design and product realization is thus occurring, and many industries, such as biomedical and aerospace, are poised to benefit. Some examples include (1) on-site, rapid fabrication of metallic bone implants with patient and injury-specific designs, and (2) fabrication of replacement parts in remote locations (e.g. outer space). Nonetheless, metallic parts made by current additive manufacturing methods tend to have porosity and anisotropy, features typically detrimental to part strength and fatigue resistance. Such parts cannot be used with confidence in load-bearing applications. This award supports scientific investigation that can potentially enable production of fatigue resistant metallic parts by additive manufacturing.

The objectives of this research are (1) to establish relationships between microstructure properties (grain orientation, and morphology), porosity distribution (size, shape, and location), and process parameters (laser power, scanning speed, hatch spacing, and layer orientation); and (2) to understand effects of microstructure properties (grain orientation) and porosity of additively-manufactured materials on their multi-axial fatigue resistance. To achieve the first objective, continuum-scale thermophysical models will be developed and used to relate microstructure properties and porosity distribution to process parameters. These models will be experimentally validated. Ti-6Al-4V specimens will be fabricated using laser-based additive manufacturing under various process parameter combinations. The layer orientation will be altered between 0ยบ-90ยบ, while scanning speed, hatch spacing, and laser power will be varied within ranges prescribed from existing knowledge (e.g. published experimental data). Microstructure properties and porosity distribution of fabricated specimens will be measured using X-ray tomography (size, shape, and location of porosity), as well as optical and scanning electron microscopy (grain orientation, and morphology). To achieve the second objective, multi-axial microstructure-sensitive fatigue models based on critical plane approaches will be developed and validated by experiments. Multi-axial fatigue experiments will be conducted on fabricated specimens, using in-phase and out-of-phase discriminating load paths to exercise different critical loading planes. Fractography on the fracture surface of specimens will be performed to determine location, size, and shape of the pore(s) responsible for initiating cracks. Crack replication techniques will be employed to find the orientation of fatigue micro-cracks with respect to critical loading plane and to determine effects of anisotropic microstructure on fatigue behavior. Through the collaboration with the Korea Institute of Industrial Technology, the generated models will be tested on other additive manufacturing methods and materials.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metal additive manufacturing (AM) is a process of joining materials track by track and layer by layer using a heat source and metal feedstock which can be powder or wire. This manufacturing method has enabled the fabrication of customized parts with complex geometries that were once impossible or infeasible to fabricate using traditional manufacturing methods. AM is enabling the fourth industrial revolution and advancing manufacturing capabilities of the aerospace, biomedical and automotive industries within the United States. However, there have been two major roadblocks against the widespread adoption of AM technology; 1) lack of sufficient knowledge regarding the structural integrity, in particular fatigue performance, of additive manufactured (AMed) parts, and 2) lack of a trained workforce (from machine operators to designers and quality engineers) with an appropriate understanding of AM processes, opportunities and challenges. Accordingly, the goal of this project was to test, and disseminate the results generated from, the hypothesis that the structural integrity of AMed parts can be enhanced via improved process planning and design parameter selection as to minimize material defects and/or to reduce their detrimental effects.

Due to limitations in current metals AM technology and an insufficient knowledge base, defects (e.g. porosity) and directional material characteristics in AMed parts are common.  These traits are detrimental to AMed part strength and the predictability of their fatigue performance.  As such, there has been hesitation to use AM in critical applications. A primary goal of this project was to investigate the possibility of using AM for the production of fatigue resistant metallic parts. The important underlying physical phenomena affecting AMed part quality were identified and the influence of the manufacturing process and design parameters on these influential factors were investigated. It has been found that, by adjusting process and design parameters and taking advantage of directional material properties, the fatigue performance and durability of AMed parts can be significantly improved. By validating this approach and establishing a better understanding of the feedstock-process-structure-property-performance interrelationships, AMed parts can be designed for specific service conditions with known loading constraints, i.e. ?design-for-application.? This type of tailored design approach can ultimately lead to safer, more reliable AMed parts across a variety of industries which can expedite the widespread adoption of metals AM. These findings have been disseminated through peer-reviewed journal publications, as well as domestic conference presentations, and training workshops.

This project has helped improve the understanding of the structural integrity and durability of AMed parts under realistic service conditions. These discoveries are the first step in bridging the gap between the benefits offered by AM and the realistic, application constraints inherent to AMed parts.  By determining how the fatigue strength of AMed parts depends on the AM process, this project has contributed toward the more rapid development of standards, qualification procedures and certification requirements ? which all support the repeatable production and safe/dependable use of AM for critical aerospace (e.g. airplane parts) and biomedical (e.g. bone implants) applications.  AM system manufacturers and end-users all benefit through the generation of better standards and quality control, as AM part design freedoms and constraints become better realized.  The promise of highly complex, structurally sound parts enabled via AM can lead to light-weight structures that meet or even surpass strength and durability requirements while offering cost/energy reduction benefits. In the biomedical industry, the ability to tailor surgical implants to an individual patient and injury can lead to lower surgery times as well as increased acceptance rates.

The project has integrated the participation and training of several undergraduate and graduate students, including those from traditionally-underrepresented groups.  Through both research activities and traditional, lecture-style courses (developed at Auburn University (AU)), these students have been taught the design, simulation, manufacturing, testing, and analysis phases of AM.  Upon graduation, these students will be among the best trained within the emerging AM workforce and will join regulatory agencies, industries, and academic institutions across the country.  Their unique training and exposure to AM will allow them to have a pronounced impact on the Nation?s manufacturing sector.

With the support of this project, a partnership has been established between AU and Huntsville City Schools (Huntsville, AL) which exposes K-12 students to AM technology. Through hands-on demonstrations and experience with state-of-the-art metals AM systems, these high school students are expected to have a higher probability of pursuing STEM-related careers within the United States. This project has also helped initiate a strategic research collaboration between professors at AU and scientists/engineers at the Korea Institute of Technology (KITECH) in South Korea.  This research collaboration has focused on using metals AM to benefit the marine and automotive industries.  Finally, this project has helped support the founding of the National Center for Additive Manufacturing Excellence (NCAME), which involves several private companies and governmental agencies - all working together to perform research for improving the fatigue resistance of AMed parts.


Last Modified: 05/31/2019
Modified by: Nima Shamsaei

This manufacturing method has enabled the fabrication of customized parts with complex geometries that were once impossible or infeasible to fabricate using traditional manufacturing methods. Finally, this project has helped support the founding of the National Center for Additive Manufacturing Excellence (NCAME), which involves several private companies and governmental agencies - all working together to perform research for improving the fatigue resistance of AMed parts.
